g.title: Breeder reactors make more fissile material than they consume. They have been built before, but are not in common use.
These can be standard water reactors or more breeder reactors.
This is enriched Uranium, with about 4 percent U-235 and the rest U-238.

path.title: This is enriched Uranium, with about 4 percent U-235 and the rest U-238.

g.title: Since the fission products decay to stability on the order of 300 years, the repository does not need to last for a million years, as it does with standard nuclear waste.
Waste from breeder reactors will have the same basic components as standard nuclear waste, but it will have significantly more fissile material in it (Plutonium or U-233 from a Thorium cycle)
The recycling plant chemically separates the nuclear waste into depleted uranium, plutonium, and the fission products.

These are the fission products that U or Pu split into, so they are about half as large as Uranium. They are often radioactive, but decay to stability much faster than standard nuclear waste, which includes heavy actinides like Plutonium, Am, and Np
Some of the breeders waste can be used to refuel the breeder for another cycle.
Since the breeder makes extra fissile material, it can fuel several other reactors as well as itself.
These can be standard water reactors or more breeder reactors.
These can be standard water reactors or more breeder reactors.
The waste from these plants can also be recycled in a closed fuel cycle.
Natural uranium ore is extracted from the ground at the mine. The enrichment plant increases the concentration of U-235 in the natural uranium up to around 4 percent.
